dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor's MOM and DAD share the couch with SPARKY THE DOG, 30-odd pounds of canine goodness. They're watching the homemade movie through vintage 3D glasses. Behind them run two projectors, manned by the filmmaker himself, VICTOR. He's more mad scientist than film auteur -- he built this twin projector system himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's where my candlestick went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, isn't that your grandmother's table cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That looks great! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   2

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: The pterodactyl swoops across town. People run in fear and panic. The monster attacks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh that is so...Woah! I just felt I was attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. That's scary. Troops and tanks spring into action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send in the marines!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over here men. This way. To no avail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Watch out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky that's you! Sparky barks as he sees himself in the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell em' Sparky. Sparky defeats the monster and the troops and townsfolk rejoice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo! Suddenly, one of the projectors JAMS on a splice. The film melts, then the tail WHIPS AROUND, getting snared in the second projector's reel. The two machines SMASH TOGETHER in a shower of sparks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!   Oh! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2       3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um. Maybe just unplug it. Sparky YANKS the power cord from the wall.     The bulb dims. The spinning stops. Darkness for a moment, then Victor flicks on the light switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it certainly was exciting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was a big finish. Well done son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fix this. C'mon boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor lugs the two projector upstairs.   Sparky follows behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that time he spends up there. A boy his age needs to be outside with his friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that Victor has friends, dear. Other than Sparky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor walks up the stairs into the attic.     Sparky is right behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my point! I don't want him to turn out, y'know, weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with Victor. He's just in his own world. MUSIC RISES as we finally enter... Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAIN   TITLES begin, as Victor carries the projector up into   his attic workshop. Sparky follows at his feet and they   pass various inventions and movie set pieces that cram   every corner of this sloped-roof wonderland. Victor disassembles the projectors, nimbly swapping pieces in and out. Sparky happily trots on a little treadmill Victor designed. He stops to scratch himself and slides out of frame. He bounds back a second later and tries to get Victor to play with him by licking his face. Victor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy boy. Victor finishes his tinkering and splices the broken film. Satisfied, he snaps the reel back on the projector and starts to roll it again. On the reel of the projector we -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on the wheel of the paper boy's bicycle we pull out to reveal the suburban paradise of New Holland. It's a sea of cookie-cutter houses on cul-de-sac'd streets named after trees. The town comes complete with its own ersatz Dutch windmill, which lazily turns on the hillside above. A BIKE-RIDING PAPERBOY delivers the morning news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky runs out the front door and grabs the newspaper for Dad. Dad kisses Mom goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good day! Dad heads to his car. Sparky picks up the newspaper in his mouth, then trots back to the house, where Victor is waiting. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor! Come on honey your going to be late. Go put Sparky in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Sparky! Victor takes Sparky around to the side of the house. He throws a ball for Sparky which lands on the edge of his neighbours meticulous garden lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Burgemeister! Next-door neighbor BURGEMEISTER is trimming his box hedge. The Mayor of New Holland, Burgemeister is slightly OCD and largely insufferable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dog has been sniffing around my Dutch Dazzlers. The other day I caught him peeing on my flamingo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll keep an eye on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Victor continues to walk to the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on Sparky. That's right. Good boy. Sparky trots after Victor.   Victor puts him in the back yard and waves good bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later! Burgemeister picks up his own newspaper and unfolds it to read the front page. INSERT NEWSPAPER: The headline reads "MAYOR BURGERMEISTER TO KICK OFF DUTCH DAYS." A photo shows Mayor Burgemeister complete with sash and hat. Burgemeister is pleased with the photo. WIDER: A girl Victor's age tries to sneak out of the house behind Burgemeister. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ELSA VAN HELSING. She's a raven-haired fourth- grader with the soul of a poet. With eyes in the back of his head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think you're going? She freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School. He turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so. What about that dog of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not in the house and she's away from your tulips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to remember something, while your parents are away I am in charge here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Uncle Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch Day is coming up and I don't need any trouble. How's your song coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep at it. Dutch day is a big day for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir. He's finished.    Has nothing more to say. Elsa walks away, happy to be out of that conversation. Burgemeister goes back to admiring his photo in the newspaper. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. RZYKRUSKI stands at the blackboard, where he's written his name. He has a thick, impossible-to-place accent, somewhere between a Russian spy and Dracula.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning children. I am Mr. Rzykruski. I will be your new science teacher. Apparently, Mr. Holcum had an incident. Edgar interjects:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got hit by lightning. This is news to Mr. Rzykruski. The rest of the class, including Victor and every child we've met so far, already knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. That is bad. But he did not get "hit by" lightning. Lightning does not hit a person, the way one is hit by a baseball or a cabbage. On the blackboard, he draws a diagram to illustrate his point, starting with a big cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning is simply electricity. The cloud is angry, yes, making storm. All the electrons are saying, "I am leaving you. I go to land of opportunity." He draws the ground beneath it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ground says, "Yes, we need electrons trained in science just like you. Come! Come! Welcome!" So both sides start to build a ladder. (drawing stick figure) This man, he comes out to look at the storm. He does not see the invisible ladders. When the two ladders meet, BOOM! The circuit is complete and all of the electrons rush to the land of opportunity. This man is in the way. Yiii! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2     8 He draws "shock lines" all around the stick figure.   It' pretty violent. All of the students are watching in wide-eyed wonder. Realizing that he may have gone overboard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But is very rare to have such incident. Victor raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not rare. Lightning happens to people all the time here. There's a thunderstorm almost every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad got hit twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They built New Holland on an abandoned gold mine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard it was a cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where they buried the miners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the windmill that does it. REVEAL a view of the windmill through the classroom window. We PUSH IN on Nassor, the intense look in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning, turning the air until the sky itself rages against the night. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Cemetery. Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky amusing himself while Victor is at school by playing with a tennis ball. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But "catch" doesn't work too well without Victor and the ball rolls through a broken plank in the bottom of Mr Burgemeister's fence. Assuming it is lost forever, Sparky sits dejectedly looking at the fence until he is startled to see the ball suddenly roll back towards him. He BARKS and goes to investigate. Another dog BARKS BACK. Surprised, Sparky backs off.   There's not usually a dog next door. He BARKS. An ANSWERING BARK. He SNIFFS the fence thoroughly. As he reaches the broken plank, his nose touches ANOTHER DOG'S NOSE. He jumps back. Lies low in the grass to peer through. On the other side of the fence is a similarly-sized poodle named PERSEPHONE -- Elsa's dog. She's beautiful. She drops the ball on the grass, staring back. Sparky suddenly rolls over on his back, completely submissive. Persephone grabs the ball and runs away. Sparky pops up, looking after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell RINGS.   Students head for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students on your way out, take a permission slip for the Science Fair. Nassor takes a form.   Reads it. They are intrigued but don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (per the form) First prize is a huge trophy! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2     10

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Victor, kneeling as he locks his bike to the rack. A SHADOW falls across him. He looks up to see WEIRD GIRL standing over him. She has a fluffy white CAT in her arms, which she strokes idly like a James Bond villain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Whiskers had a dream about you last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this morning, he made this. She holds out what looks to be a small rope of dried clay, bent in shape of a V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get that out of the litter box?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an omen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last month he dreamed about Bob. She shows BOB, a chubby classmate, a cat-poop `B.' In a STYLIZED, OVERLAPPING SPLIT-SCREEN, we see Bob walking down a sidewalk, eating an ice-cream cone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fell in a manhole. Bob suddenly drops out of frame.   TILT DOWN to see the open manhole. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dreamed about Toshiaki the day he pitched a perfect game. Weird Girl shows classmate TOSHIAKI a cat-poop `T.' Wearing a baseball cap, Toshiaki stares intently, ready to make his pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Nassor the day he got knocked unconscious. Nassor, an intense boy with sinister eyes, pulls down a catcher's mask. A slit of light on his eyes. Toshiaki throws. The ball hits Nassor square on the mask, knocking him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Mr. Whiskers dreams about you, it means something big is going to happen. She offers him the "V."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can keep it. The class bell RINGS.     Side-stepping around her, Victo heads in to class. She holds the cat to her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day you'll dream about me, won't you kitty? Mr. Whiskers offers nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor hops off his bike and goes into the backyard where Sparky has been waiting for him to come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey boy. How you doing? Suddenly the backyard gate bursts open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be my partner, right, Victor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you have to have a partner for the science fair and whoever's your partner is going to win. You know the most about science. So pick me as a partner. I have lots of ideas. We could make a death ray! Victor holds up a permission slip, which lists all the prohibited projects, including explosives, lasers, nuclear devices and death rays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says no death rays.    See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, man. I still want to do it. (and yet...) C'mon. Who else would be your partner? You don't have friends and neither do I. He has a point.   Victor gives in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Edgar. I just don't need a partner. I like to work alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad is examining the permission slip. Mom is bringing food in from the kitchen -- they're having fondue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sign my permission slip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor, have I ever talked to you about what I do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a travel agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sell dreams. I tell people, you can sail to Italy. You can do the hula in Hawaii.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sign my form?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting to that. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   13

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Dad picks up two long fondue forks, using them to illustrate his point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my job, sometimes you have people who don't want quite the same thing, right. Say the husband wants to play golf in Scotland, but the wife wants to paddle down the Amazon. Alright you've got two conflicting ideas here. (holding forks apart) And it's my job, Victor, to help them meet halfway. Say, Scottsdale, Arizona. He gets to golf, she gets Indians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's no river. And no jungle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody gets what they want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. And wrong. They both get what they want because they compromise. Dad skewers meat on his forks, continuing his metaphor. Victor is shrimp; Dad is beef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd like to do this science fair. And that's great. I'd like you to try a sport. Say, I don't know, baseball. Science fair, baseball. Science fair, baseball. How do you choose? Guess what? You don't have to. No reason you can't do both. You meet in the middle. (bringing forks together) Everyone's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor is stood on the side of the baseball field with his Dad who is head coach. Sparky is there aswell to support Victor. Toshiaki is pitching. Nassor is catching. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2     14

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at what Toshiaki's doing. Keeping his eye on the target. Never losing his concentration. Toshiaki pitches and the batter misses. Nassor catches the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike three! Next Batter! Camera PANS to find Mr. Rzykruski -- who is simply in Victor's imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to concentrate on your project for the science fair. We continue to pan past Mr Ryzkruski and come back onto Victor trying in vain to keep focused on the game. Toshiaki winds up for the pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor's Mom is in the stands for the big game -- along with all the kids we've met so far, and many of the adults. Sparky is completely taken by the ball and his eyes follow it around the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on honey! Toshiaki pitches again and as Victor swings to hit the ball Sparky leaps up catching the ball mid jump. The other kids snigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice catch Sparky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Victor, please. Tie Sparky up and get your head into the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time out! Victor takes Sparky to the bleachers and ties him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry boy. He walks back onto the field. Elsa arrives at the bleachers with Persephone. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   15

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Sparky. She sits on the bleachers with Persephone to watch the game. Sparky looks over admiringly at Persephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play ball. Victor swings for the ball again. And misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice try son. Once again Victor remembers wise words of Mr Ryzkruski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rzykruski stands in front of the classroom black board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When conducting an experiment, trying is the important thing. It is OK to fail as long as you keep trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on the field at the bleachers Weird Girl arrives with Mr Whiskers. She sits by Elsa and Peresphone. They exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Victor- you can do it! Toshiaki pitches again and again Victor misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on honey! Elsa, Weird Girl and Mr Whiskers will Victor on. This time when Victor swings - He hits! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2      16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He almost forgets to run until Sparky BARKS at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor run! Sparky pulls on his lead and it works loose. The ball rolls out of the park. Sparky goes after it, his stubby legs bounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Sparky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ball rolls into the street and Sparky manages to grab it in his mouth. Proud of himself, Sparky turns to look back at Victor. Just then...

dialogues.speaker: A CAR
dialogues.text: SCREECHES up at him.      Sparky reacts.    We CUT AWAY a car hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every player, every kid, every parent is stunned. Horrified. We end CLOSE ON Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! Noooooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad buries a wooden box. Victor watches at the grave side, devastated. His Mom and Dad give him a quiet moment to grieve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Persephone nudges the tennis ball through the gap in the fence. She's waiting for Sparky. Disappointed, she leaves the ball and slowly walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor lies in bed, staring up at the ceiling. Mom and Dad sit on the edge of the bed, trying to comfort him. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    17

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a great dog.    A great friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best dog a kid could have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you lose someone you love, they never really leave you. They just move into a special place in your heart. He'll always be there, Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want him in my heart.    I want him here, with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. If we could bring him back, we would. Mom kisses Victor goodnight and turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and get some sleep sweet heart- things will seem better in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his attic workshop, Victor is finishing work on his projector. He threads the film and starts it playing. Sparky-saurus is attacking the Pterodactyl. Victor smiles for a moment, then the sadness returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor's sadness remains as we travel through a changing scene around him- in his bedroom, at breakfast, in the car on the way to school and finally in the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at school Victor is despondent. Unable to concentrate, he doodles pictures of Sparky in his notebook and barely listens to the lecture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like lightning, the nervous system is electricity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are wires and springs and cables to send the messages. "Foot! Move! You are standing in the fire!" Mr. Ryzkruski lifts up a plate with a cloth on. He reveals a dead frog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eww!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even after death, the wiring remains. Watch as the muscles respond to the electricity. Mr Ryzkruski places the frog onto his desk and begins to hook an electrode to its leg. The wiring is attached to a small box that can generate an electric charge. Mr Ryzkruski now attaches the electrode to the frog's leg and, with a flip of a switch, turns on the electricity - The frog leg jumps up as if alive! And so does Victor. He looks back and forth between Mr. Ryzkruski's demonstration and his doodle of Sparky. An idea. Victor bursts out of the school doors and starts to run home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor runs through the street on his way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs into the garage and grabs a whole lot of tools, gear and equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor raids the kitchen for some household appliances. Mom sits on the couch reading and only barely registers what he is up to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Victor, how was school? Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   19

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok. Victor heads upstairs with a box of the appliances he has just collected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A full moon.    HOOTING owls. Over the top of the fence, we see a shovel blade moving past. The shovel digs into the soft earth.   Again.   And again Victor is digging up Sparky's grave. It's tough work, especially because he's trying to be quiet. A black cat perches on a nearby gravestone.     SCREECHES Spooked, Victor waves him off. He's uncovered the box. He opens it and gingerly loads the wrapped bundle into shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor's parents are sitting on the couch watching a movie. Though the movie isn't really scary, Mom looks for any excuse to snuggle closer to her husband. He playfully encourages it and puts his arm around her to pull her closer. As Victor sneaks behind them, carrying the wrapped corpse, he inadvertently knocks into a lamp causing it to flicker. Dad turns and sees what's back there but can't see Victor who is hiding, frozen, just out of sight. Dad turns back to the TV. Relieved, Victor tiptoes past them, heading for the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREMELY CLOSE ON the eye of a needle.   Thread pushes through. Victor is making repairs to Sparky's corpse. We don't see any of it directly, just shadows on the wall. He rummages through a bucket of nuts and screws, picking two oversized bolts. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2     20 He places Sparky onto Mom's ironing board and pushes it directly under the skylight. The storm is just reaching a fever pitch. As HOPEFUL MUSIC rises, Victor climbs a ladder out the window where we see that he has attached his metal swing set to the roof. Victor checks the wind direction and lets fly two balloons attached to the umbrella and fastens the ends to the swing set. This will serve as the conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burgemeister is drawing his drapes shut when he sees the movement on the Frankenstein roof. He can't make out Victor, but it's enough to make him suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor climbs down and checks his notes and his equipment. We see a whole host of household items that Victor has re purposed to become part of his elaborate apparatus. - A series of Mom's colanders and pans and appliances, - an old fish tank, - some bobbing Christmas reindeer all serve as unlikely components of his grand experiment. He has also erected a series of pulleys so that he can hoist Sparky up through the sky light. Victor can hear the storm raging and knows that it is now or never. He pets Sparky's lifeless form one last time for courage. He turns to an old Schwinn bicycle mounted on a stand and starts the wheels spinning. One by one the appliances start to whir and come alive. Victor then begins to hoist Sparky up through the sky light. The rain is beating down and the lightning is getting more intense. The metal table finally reaches his resting spot under the swing set. Now all he can do is wait. He watches the storm intently, silently urging Zeus' thunderbolts to strike. And then... Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2      21

dialogues.speaker: CRACK
dialogues.text: A jagged finger of light touches the top of the balloons, racing down the cord and into the attic - Zapping Sparky with a thousand volts. Victor removes his goggles, and springs right to action cranking down the metal table, eager to see if it worked. All of the appliances power down and grind to a halt. The room goes silent. He swings the table over to the workbench. Wearing a stethoscope, he listens for a heartbeat. Hearing nothing, he keeps checking. But he eventually realizes it has all been for naught. He lays his head down on the workbench, letting out exhausted, sniffly tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, boy. A beat. As a single tear drips onto Sparky's lifeless form, we hear a final spark and then... His TAIL starts to move and   - His TONGUE licks Victor face. Victor sits up, bewildered.   It's Sparky, still half- wrapped in the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're alive! You're alive! Sparky! You're Alive! I can't believe it you're alive! Sparky can't control how happy he is and knocks Victor to the group. He enthusiastically licks his face and wags his tail so excitedly that it flies clear across the room. For a moment, he looks worried but Victor just laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fix that. Victor and Sparky play on the attic floor excited to be back together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It worked. It really worked. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    22

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor is sleeping on the floor, sharing a blanket with Sparky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor's Mom opens the door to find Victor's bed empty. Pretty sure where he must be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor!     Breakfast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky licks Victor's face waking him up. He sits up, rubbing his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC STAIRS- DAY
dialogues.text: Mom is walking up the stairs to the attic looking for Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor?     Are you up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor hears his Mom climbing the steps and panics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssh! Quiet down boy! Ssssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor? Victor picks up Sparky and carries him around a curtain to the back of the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! Sssh! Quiet. Mom enters but can't see Victor and Sparky behind the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor? Looking around for somewhere to hide Sparky, Victor finally grabs a big tin bucket and puts it over Sparky just as - Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   23 Mom pulls the curtain back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French toast or waffles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll need my waffle iron back, Mr. Director. Spotting her waffle iron amid the leftover set decoration, she heads right for Sparky. The bucket suddenly moves, shifting away. She looks at Victor.   Thinking quick:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my science project.   It's a robot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A robotic bucket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For mopping, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe when you're finished, you'll let me use it. She takes her waffle iron and heads back downstairs. Victor closes the curtain, then lifts the bucket off Sparky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, boy, but I can't let anyone know about you. They may not understand. So you need to stay here today. Victor kisses Sparky and heads out of the attic. Sparky rests his head on his paws, dejected. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor walks down the sidewalk to school. He looks up at the open attic window, nervous to be leaving Sparky alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it, there! Victor stops, realizing he's stepped off the sidewalk, and has almost nudged the edge of one of Burgemeister's tulips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm really sorry. Burgemeister glares at him suspiciously. He doesn't trust this kid and suspects that something weird is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom is vacuuming while reading a book.    She's quite practiced at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky is drinking from his water bowl.   As he does, water leaks from his seams. He hears a LONG MEOW. It's Mr. Whiskers, Weird Girl's Cat and it's perched in the open attic window. Sparky BARKS at it. Mom switches off the vacuum.    Did she hear barking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Couldn't be. She starts up the vacuum again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky jumps up on a chair, then onto the workbench. Lunges for the cat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and goes right through the window. He lands on the steeply-sloped roof and slides down the shingles, falling... Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...right past the picture window. Fortunately, Mom is so engrossed in her book that she doesn't see him and she continues her vacuuming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky lands in the driveway and Mr Whiskers watches him from on top of the car. When he moves to make a run for it, Sparky is in hot pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky chases the cat through the tulips, smashing them. Mr Whiskers bounds on top of one of Mr. Burgemeister's flamingos and thinks he is safely out of Sparky's reach. He smugly starts to groom himself, but the single standing leg starts to buckle. The flamingo collapses into a heap, spilling the cat onto the perfectly manicured flowers, destroying everything. The cat and Sparky run past the house and into the neighbor's backyard just as Mr Burgemeister looks out the window to see his destroyed garden.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BOB'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr Whiskers leaps onto a garbage can, and clambers up onto the roof to safety. Sparky unable to follow is distracted by a fly buzzing around the knocked over garbage can. He gulps it down and then suddenly stops. He feels a funny tickle in his throat, neck and tummy before the fly emerges from the stitches on his side. Sparky continues to chase the fly into Bob's yard where Bob's Mom is hanging out the laundry. As she turns, she sees Sparky's shadow cast on a bed sheet. The shadow is double his size and his teeth look huge. Bob's Mom thinks it's a hideous monster and runs screaming into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! *screams* Sparky can't understand why she is so upset but he just heads out on his way. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two MOMS sit on a park bench talking, while their toddlers nap in their strollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, and Helen said she thought he was putting up some kind of tv antenna on top of the roof!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of a thunderstorm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what she said! Neither mother notices as Sparky trots up. One of the babies starts to fall asleep and drops his pacifier on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you get that big power surge in the night? Jack thought it was a fuse box but apparently it effected the whole neighbourhood. The baby looks round and sees Sparky guilelessly sucking on the pacifier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder just what goes on in that house. I just don't feel safe walking by there. Seeing Sparky up close, the baby is horrified.   It SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie are you ok? Here you go. Sparky hides under the bench out of sight as the first woman tries to calm her little one and pops the pacifier back in the babies mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So anyway Jack loves it here but if the schools weren't so great sometimes I wonder if we would be better of... Both Mommies get up and start to walk away they don't notice Sparky cowering under the bench. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky trots past the front of the school as the school bell rings. Sparky heads for the garbage cans around the back. On his way home, E walks behind the cafeteria and sees Sparky sniffing around the garbage cans. He can't believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Sparky stops short and looks right at E before running off home. E's eyes narrow.     Isn't Sparky supposed to be dead? We end on a shot of E, hatching a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky arrives home and heads straight to the backyard fence to see if Persephone is around. Seeing that she is, he peeks his head through the broken slates. Persephone is overjoyed but she seems to know that there's something different about him. Sparky is so excited to see her he pushes his head through the hole and gets his bolts stuck on the fence. Persephone comes over to get a closer look and sniffs at him cautiously. He smells a little funny but he seems to be the same old Sparky until she focuses on the bolts sticking out of his neck. Cautiously, she licks one, and gets

dialogues.speaker: ZAPPED
dialogues.text: The force of the spark sends Sparky back through the fence and into his own yard. Persephone is thrown clear across her garden. As she woozily gets back up, she turns and we see that she now has a Bride of Frankenstein stripe in her hair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor cycles home after school. He throws his bike on the lawn and heads straight inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom is lying on the couch, reading one of her books. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2     28

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Victor.   How was school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GoodGottaGo. He's heads up the stairs just as Sparky walks through the front door, following a few steps behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor enters the attic, looking for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Hearing no answer, he walks in further.    He checks behi the curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Slight panic creeps into Victor's voice before Sparky sneaks in behind him and nudges his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. Good boy! Relieved, Victor kneels down and pets him lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry you had to stay here alone all day. Sparky just keeps panting, not revealing a thing. He starts to slow down coming to a rest at Victor feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter boy? Are you ok? Hmmm. You're a little low. Are you hungry, boy? Sparky sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, here lets top you up. Victor runs an extension cord from the wall and clips them to Sparky's bolts. As he switches the plug on, Sparky's eyes glow a bit. Sparky brightens up and barks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor!   Could you come down here please? Victor switches the plug off and heads downstairs. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   29

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN- DAY
dialogues.text: Victor is taken by surprise as enters the kitchen to find Edgar sitting at the counter. Edgar looks particularly smug as Mom is busies herself in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor your friend is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know what you know I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't know what you think I know, but I don't know it. Mom exits the kitchen and Edgar leans in, barely able to hide his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dog is alive. Victor looks shocked and checks to see if Mom has gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I know it is so impossible but you did it. You did it. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   30 Victor stalls, trying to think of an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So show me how, or I'll tell everyone. Oh Mrs Frankenstein...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssh! Mom comes back into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .. May I have a cookie please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh- yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Come on. Victor reluctantly agrees and beckons Edgar to follow him up to the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky and E watch as Victor draws his findings on the chalkboard for E. It's a mess of symbols and variables, all connected by arrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the wind and the lightning are part of the same thing, some kind of strange force. But the wind isn't strong enough to bring an animal back from the dead. For that, you need lightning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when can I do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't. This isn't an experiment. It's my dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show and tell Victor:   you show me and I won't tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E stares into a tank of swimming goldfish, the PET STORE OWNER appears next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you young man? Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to buy a fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.   Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one. He points to one floating belly-up at the top of the tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E plops the dead fish into a small jar of water, already attached to electrodes and the metal table. Victor and E crank the gears, opening the roof to the stormy night sky. The table rises into position as the lightning rod telescopes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do now? Victor grabs E and throws him to the floor. Sparky finds cover behind a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CRACK
dialogues.text: The table cranks back down into the attic. The roof doors fold shut. Victor and E race over to the jar. CLOSE ON E as he looks into the little jar. The fish is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to it?    What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.    It should have worked. Victor leans in to look close.    Suddenly, the water ripples. A PLOP. Then the jar RATTLES AROUND on its rim, knocked about from within. Victor finds a steampunk-ish flashlight with different lenses that spin in front of the bulb. As he holds it close to the jar, we see what appears to be a transperant fish skeleton swimming around. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in wonderment) It's invisible. It's an invisible goldfish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is it invisible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Sparky growls at the jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nightly storm has ended.     It's now just a bit of distant RUMBLING. E is carrying the jar with the invisible goldfish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't tell anyone. You understand that, right? Not until we figure out how it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay!    Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise. We see E crossing his fingers behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toshiaki and Bob stand in the door way of the garage examining E's jar with healthy skepticism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we supposed to see an invisible goldfish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your finger in.       You can feel it. Toshiaki and Bob trade a look -- this feels like a prank. But with a shrug, Bob does. Nothing.   He swirls his finger around. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaah! He yanks his finger out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It bit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it. Toshiaki takes the jar from E. He walks over to a table and places the jar down. He shines a table lamp through the jar. The invisible goldfish casts a shadow on the wall. In the shadow, you can see it actually has Jurassic-sized teeth. It's pretty scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toshiaki turns off the lamp and takes a closer look at the jar. E takes the jar back.    Screws on the lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my science project and it's top secret. Toshiaki looks over to Bob and gives him a flick of the head. Bob takes the hint and starts to push E out of the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, our science fair project is even cooler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double top secret. Toshiaki pulls the garage door shut in Edgar's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toshiaki and Bob take a critical look at their science fair project: SEA MONKEYS - THE TRUTH REVEALED! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sea monkeys. We gotta come up with something better. Bigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The science fair is in two days!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the smart one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! A long beat. Toshiaki's eyes narrow. He stares at Bob and his gaze then moves to the poster above Bob's head, it's a Rocket Poster. Toshiaki has an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky is desperate to play with Victor in the attic. Victor tries to quieten him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, ok, sit still. Ssssh! Sparky. No! Sssh. No! Sssh. Victor ties up Sparky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, boy. But we can't risk anyone seeing you again. Victor starts to leave, he turns at the curtain as Sparky barks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssh! Sparky lies down, head on his paws, sad and lonely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The school bell rings. E is leaving school with the other kids. He nearly bumps into Nassor who is waiting for him. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2      35

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toshiaki says you have an invisible fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.       Who said I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toshiaki says it's your science fair project.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it was, I couldn't tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it isn't?    Or it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    Yes.   I'm confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have an invisible fish? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But you have to keep it a secret. He unzips his school bag, pulling out the jar of water. Unscrews the lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swish your finger around.      You can feel it. Nassor dips his finger in the water, swirling it around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just water. There's nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's invisible? E dips his own finger in, feeling for his toothy goldfish. He's puzzled when he can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   36 PUSHING IN ominously...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what kind of game you and Victor are playing. But that trophy will be mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Gasp* A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E runs as fast as he can with his jar outstretched in front of him, catching up to Victor. It's just the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor! Something's wrong with my fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not there anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it just hopped out.   Did you have the lid on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Ever since...since I left your house. I mean, it was there when I went to bed. Victor ponders the possibilities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking, maybe they don't last. They're only there for a little bit and then they're gone. Suddenly panicked, Victor runs back to his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor runs up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor runs through the attic. He pulls the curtain back his eyes go right to where he left Sparky tied up. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rope is still there.    But his dog is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Gasp* No!    Sparky! *Gasp* A BARK. Victor turns to find Sparky drinking out of his bowl. He scratches his ear and it falls off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! Victor rushes over to him. Sparky's not sure what all the drama is about but does seem slightly concerned with his lost ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Don't worry. I can fix that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor is in bed.    He reaches under the bed to pat Sparky's head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, boy. ...then switches off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's Mom is having a drink in the garden. She slurps the last few drops before she heaves herself up to go inside for a refill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is nervous.    Looking back over his shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is going to work? Toshiaki is shaking a soda bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's why it's called an experiment. We have to collect data. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have to collect it on me? WIDER, we see that Bob is wearing a modified backpack. Lashed to it are nine two-liter container of soda, caps pointing down, each with a pull-string. Toshiaki attaches the tenth and final bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten.    Nine.    Eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use a test dummy or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.    Six.    Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer simulation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four.    Three.    Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to pee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One. Toshiaki yanks the cord.     The soda BLASTS out the bott of the jet-pack. Toshiaki grabs his video camera to document their success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoah, woah, w-w-w-woah woah, whoah, woah, woah, woah. Bob finds himself hovering in fits and starts and actually gets a bit airborne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) It's working. It's working! Through the lens we see Bob hover in the air for a long moment before he drops like a stone out of frame. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Painful murmurs* Toshiaki, still filming looks down to find Bob sprawled on the grass. His arm is bent at an impossible angle. Bob's Mom comes outside hearing the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Scream*

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-dozen NEIGHBORS and classmates have gathered to watch as Bob is loaded into an ambulance. His arm is already in a sling. BOB'S MOTHER is apoplectic:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you boys doing on the roof!? Bob and Toshiaki exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad arrive at the meeting as Mr Burgemeister starts to speak at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As mayor of New Holland, you have entrusted me with your safety. So I can't sit idly by while a teacher endangers our children. Bob's Mother is also on the stage with Bob whose arm is still in a sling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is a menace! A lot of agreement from the PARENTS in attendance. Another father stands up in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you looked through this "science" book they're using? Apparently, Pluto isn't good enough to be a planet anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, Pluto was a great planet. This guy comes along and rewrites the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fairness, he didn't write the textbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Mayor, Edward Frankenstein, your neighbour of course. I would just like to say that our son Victor is just crazy about the new teacher. Thinks he's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Cynthia has been asking all sorts of strange questions. About things I've never even heard of!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we at least give the man the chance to explain himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Please come up. Mr...Menace. He points to Mr. Rzykruski, who has been lingering at the back of the assembly room. He comes up front to the microphone. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies, Gentlemen. I think the confusion here is that you are all very ignorant. A sea of stony faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this right word, "ignorant?"    I mean simple. Primitive. Unenlightened. Not winning them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not understand science, so you are afraid of it. Like a dog is afraid of thunder, or balloons. To you, science is magic and witchcraft because you have such small minds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2     41

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot make your heads bigger, but your children's heads -- I can take them and crack them open. This is what I try to do. To get at their brains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my! Mr. Rzykruski somehow convinced he did a good job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Mr Rzykruski leaves the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, geeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsa PRACTICE-HUMS her Dutch Day song while Persephone does her business, sniffing around the bushes. Forgetting a lyric, Elsa checks a sheet she was holding behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Victor has Sparky outside in his backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quick, boy. They'll be home any minute. Sparky smells Persephone.    He sniffs along the fence.

dialogues.speaker: BOTH SIDES
dialogues.text: Persephone sniffs along the fence as well. She BARKS. Sparky BARKS back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no no no! Ssssh! He covers over Sparky's mouth. Elsa approaches the fence and stands on tippe toe so that she can just barely see over the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor? Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   42 Victor crouches low so that she can't see him and struggles to keep Sparky from barking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Elsa.    What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practicing my song for Dutch Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get a new dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard a bark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah that was me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were barking. Sparky manages to get free for a moment and lets out a howl. Victor quickly grabs his mouth shut and then tries to mimic his bark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: *Victor pretends to bark and howl* Elsa steps back from the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must really miss Sparky. HEADLIGHTS sweep across the fence.   Victor's parents are back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to go.   Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. Elsa kneels down and pets Persephone lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel so sad for him, Persephone. He really misses his dog. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    43 She tenderly kisses Persephone on the head and holds her a little closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Rzykruski walks out of the school doors carrying a cardboard box full of all his school things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gym Teacher, who is serving as substitute teacher scrubs the board clear of Mr Rzykruski's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mr. Rzykruski?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know is, I'll be teaching the class for the rest of the semester. She begins erasing the messy blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know anything about science?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know more than you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rzykruski knew a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes knowing too much is the problem. Victor looks out the window as Mr Rzykruski is packing up the trunk of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the science fair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's still on. But it will be judged by someone who is not insane -- Me! The class look skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now get cracking and may the best person win. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rzykruski is packing his strange little car with all his things from the classroom. Victor races up to him in the car park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe they let the gym teacher be the judge. She's not even interested in science. Mr. Rzykruski turns back to see his favorite student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back home, everyone is scientist. Even my plumber wins Nobel Prize. Your country does not make enough scientists. Always needs more. You should be a scientist, Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody likes scientists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They like what science gives them, but not the questions, no, not the questions that science asks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually I have a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is why you are scientist. Victor smiles, a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was doing my experiment, my project, and the first time it worked great. But the next time it didn't. I mean, it sort of worked, but then it didn't. And I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe you never really understood it the first time. Victor is puzzled, but intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People think science is here... (points to his head) ...but it is also here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to his heart). The first time, did you love your experiment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor, defeated, hangs his head in his hands. Suddenly, Sparky licks him. He's returned from the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the second time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor watches as the bolt of lightning charges the jar of water with the dead goldfish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    I just wanted it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you changed the variables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was doing it for the wrong reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Science is not good or bad, Victor. But it can be used both ways. That is why you must always be careful. With that, he offers his hand.   They shake. Victor watches as Mr. Rzykruski drives off. Bob and Toshiaki are still fuming about the science fair. Nassor is preparing for Baseball practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I broke my arm for nothing. None of us are going to win. E has an invisible fish. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    46

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he doesn't. You fell for a parlor trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying he faked it? Just then we hear a crash as E trips over a stack of bats. He has been eavesdropping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fish you showed us, was it real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was!   And it was dead, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought an animal back from the dead? The boys move in, circling him.    He panics, but can't g away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Victor did. With lightning and BOOM! and SSS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear! I mean, he already brought back his dog. He tries to swallow his words but the boys lean in closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brought back Sparky? E nods and the boys exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor will win the science fair. Unless we can do better. Bigger. Toshiaki turns his steely gaze towards Edgar and a sly smile spreads across his face. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say you know Victor's secret. Now is your chance to prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's recipe book is opened to a page that reads -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, where is my muffin tin? She checks inside the oven but no muffin tin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing) Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTOR'S MOM goes up into the attic to find... Nothing out of the ordinary. She enters, taking a look around for her missing muffin tin. She walks over to Victor's chalk board and sees his diagrams for bringing Sparky back to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Sparky walks around the curtain and stands panting next to Mom. She turns, startled and sees - Sparky. His NECK BOLTS. His STITCHES. Mom falls backwards and onto the floor and - SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad enters the house to hear Mom screaming in the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad runs in and see's Sparky desperately trying to get closer to Mom. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? ... Sparky's alive! Sparky doesn't understand why she is screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! Hey. Come on. Sparky is petrified, he bolts away and runs into the mirror which splinters from the impact. He looks up and sees his reflection - grotesque and broken. Victor enters around the curtain and is horrified to see what is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Dad! What's going on? Sparky runs towards the window, desperate and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! Nooooo! Sparky! Victor and his Dad run to catch Sparky but he shoots past them through the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! No! Sparky come back! Sparky! Victor tries to go after him but Dad holds him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I have to go and find Sparky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor what have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said yourself: If you could bring back Sparky, you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but that was different, because we couldn't! It's easy to promise the impossible. What you did was a very serious thing. Crossing the boundary between life and death -- reanimating a corpse -- it's very...upsetting. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted my dog back. Tears well up in Victor's eyes. His anguish is palpable. Mom looks to Dad for a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweetheart, we'll help you look for Sparky but when we get back I think we need to have a little talk. Understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Mom and Dad share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now lets go find your dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky runs through town where the dutch day festivities have officially begun. The town square has been transformed into a European fun fair with rides and food stalls set up all the way down main street. People in costume are converging on hot dog vendors and beer gardens. Sparky is petrified but the townsfolk are completely oblivious. Sparky tries to stay out of sight, but everywhere he goes, he's scared off by some new terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor looks in the backyard and shines his flashlight into the empty dog house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Are you in there! Victor's parents head out the front door and Victor hurries past them on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Dad! I'm going to check out the school and the park, you guys do the town square, ok?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! As they go in their respective directions we see Toshiaki, Edgar, Nassor and Weird Girl skulking in the bushes. Toshiaki nudges Edgar forward and motions to the front door which has been left ajar in their haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the shadows of all five of them slowly climb the attic stairs. E pulls the curtain back to reveal Victor's sanctum sanctorum. The apparatus glistens in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Nassor and Weird Girl check out the equipment - pushing and pulling on the wires with clumsy curiosity. Edgar tries to confer with Toshiaki who turns his back dismissively. Its clear there are no more partnerships. Its every man for himself. Toshiaki examines the formulas and theorems on the blackboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has something to do with the lightning. I don't really understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah-but I do. PUSHING IN on his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, we shall bring the dead to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor runs around the baseball field shining the flashlight under the bleachers and into the dug out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky!    Where are you? Sparky! Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky narrowly avoids some kids running towards the town center by backing into an open gate. As the revelers pass he looks around at where he is and sees that he is surrounded by ominous looking headstones. An eerie Cat A giant turtle A flock of bats fly out from behind a tombstone and force him up the hillside where he finds himself at the foot of his own grave. He can't read, but he seems to recognize what it is. What it means. He lays down, looking up at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in town we see Victor's parents searching under the stage as the crowd starts to assemble for Dutch day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Sparky? The crowd applauds as Mr. Burgemeister steps up to the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you so much. And now, it's my pleasure to introduce this year's Little Dutch Girl, my niece, Elsa Van Helsing. Elsa walks out to meet Burgemeister on stage. She is completely transformed with wooden shoes and blond braids. In addition to her costume, she is wearing a wide crown of candles. She tries to walk very steadily to keep wax from dripping on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think this is safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. We have the fire chief over here. We see a decrepit, 90 year old man dressed like a fireman. He doesn't inspire confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, a lot of girls would kill to be in your place. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2     52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd welcome death. Burgemeister walks away from Elsa leaving her alone at the microphone. Nervous, she looks out over the crowd. Elsa starts to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Praise be New Holland, Streets so wide and sidewalks clean, Modest homes at modest prices, Everyone's urban dream, Praise be New Holland, Happy children free from tears, Free from all the worlds dangers, Free from crime and free from strangers, The crowd is so rapt that no one notices the big THUNDERSTORM brewing overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowering behind his tombstone, Sparky watches as Nassor and Toshiaki enter the graveyard, each carrying a shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) In our houses tight and safe, We have nothing to fear,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nassor heads up the hill towards a gothic mausoleum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. The tomb of Collosus soon you shall be awakened and we shall be reunited once again. Toshiaki stops in front of a tomb shaped like the shell of a turtle. The inscription reads simply - Shelley. He digs up a small bundle, he picks it up and smiles wryly. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E rummages in the school garbage cans and triumphantly pulls out a dead rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E climbs through the window of the classroom and places his dead rat on Mr. Ryzkruski's desk. He attaches the electrode clips to the rats paws.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob feeds a metal leaf skimmer into his pool and then rips open the container of sea monkeys and dumps them in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nassor enters the mausoleum and attaches two clips onto the grave of Collosus. He exits the mausoleum and sends four Mylar balloons off into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toshiaki exits the gardening shed and walks over to his bundle. He attaches two clips and hooks these up to a kite by using a series of extension cords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back through a skylight to see Mr Whiskers delivering a dead bat to Weird Girl who sits on her bed combing her doll's hair. Weird Girl's room is impossibly girly with pink fluffy flowers all around. She untwists metal coat hangers and attaches them to each other, making a long lightning rod. She lays the bat on her bed and attaches two   clips to i wings. She then grabs a large butterfly wall   hanging fr above her bed. She attaches the butterfly to   the coat hanger pole and solemnly feeds it out of the   window int the night sky. The balloons, butterfly and kite can be seen floating over New Holland in the storm. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2        54 While she stares out the window at the approaching storm, Mr Whiskers sniffs curiously at the bat and starts to take a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elsa finishes her song:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Praise be New Holland, May your windmill spin forever more. The crowd APPLAUDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she adorable. Motioning with his hands, Burgemeister signals for bigger applause but a big clap of THUNDER gets everyone's attention - And then lightning strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lightning hits the butterfly and flies down the coat hanger rod. It hits the bat which is still in Mr Whisker's mouth. The bed explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning hits the propped-up pool skimmer, then CRACKLES across the surface of the pool. Bob leaps back blinded by the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lightning strikes the school building, SURGING through the power line to the electrodes on the rat. see the flattened sections start to balloon out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mylar balloons are FRIED by lightning. The balloons burst, sending the surge hurtling down towards the mausoleum. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning surges down from the heavens, striking the disinterred bundle. The turtle bundle explodes. Toshiaki ducks for cover into the garden shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird Girl looks up she sees Mr. Whiskers. His fur is smoking but he just seems a little dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Whiskers? He starts licking his paws when suddenly -- GIANT BAT WINGS unfurl from his back. He looks up at the Weird Girl and HISSES, his mouth featuring two giant fangs. He arches his back and we see his vertebrae multiply and stretch. His paws extend into gnarled and pointy claws. His color changes from white to grey to a muddy, cloudy black. It forms a perfect vampire's peak on his head - Mr Whiskers has transformed into a VAMPIRE CAT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Whiskers? The VAMPIRE CAT starts to fly around the room manically knocking into things on shelves and on the walls. He ends up on the sky light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Whiskers. With one flap of its wings, he flies out the window and up into the stormy night sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: E races out of the classroom into the corridor screaming. Hearing the commotion the gym teacher opens a different classroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Is someone there? The gym teacher tentatively makes her way down the corridor to the classroom E has just run from. She opens the door. A beat. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   56 A giant WERERAT leaps in front of the doorway with it's fangs revealed. The gym teacher screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The earth around the mausoleum rumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise, colossus. Rise from your tomb! As Nassor continues his incantation, we see a MUMMY HAMSTER emerge from the mausoleum. His shadow is huge. Nassor watches with his mouth open his gaze moves down to the ground. It might be frightening if the Mummy Hamster weren't just a few inches tall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bottle of Miracle-Gro lies empty on the grass. Toshiaki steps out of the garden shed and walks over to the scorched patch of grass. He looks around the garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shelley? Suddenly, a massive turtle foot SMASHES down, crushing the shed. A GIANT TURTLE MONSTER -- bigger than a bus -- SHRIEKS to the heavens. Toshiaki scrambles to get away, alternately impressed and terrified. The turtle opens its mouth, and lets out a blood curdling roar. Distracted by the Dutch Day lights the Turtle monster heads to town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An almost-translucent hand grabs the side of the pool, pulling itself out. And it's not alone. Dozens of SEA MONKEYS emerge: simian warriors with shrimp-like features, some carrying bone tridents. Bob SCREAMS and runs out of the garden followed by the sea monkeys. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2    57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor stops his bike at the pet cemetery gates -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Sparky? Victor pushes open the gate. His flashlight casts long, scary shadows. He is drawn towards Sparky's grave and as his flashlight sweeps across the tombstone, he sees Sparky's frightened face peeking out from behind. Could it be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky? Sparky peers around the edge of the tombstone and realizes that it's Victor and hangs his head in shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky! Sparky is nervous and confused but slowly rests his head in Victor's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparky it's OK boy, it's just me. I thought that you were gone. I never want to lose you. Promise you'll never go running off. Okay? Victor hold him tightly and Sparky licks him happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on boy. Victor leads Sparky away through the cemetery when he sees the open grave of Shelley and the Colossus mausoleum door ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was someone else here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob runs past the pet cemetery and hides behind a mail box to avoid the phalanx of sea monkeys who charge past like supernatural hooligans, craving mayhem and destructive mischief. Panting with relief, Bob turns to see Victor in the cemetery. Final Shooting Script_2012_01_18_v2   58

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor! I need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see those things? They were like....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sea Monkeys. You know how on the package, they're like in a happy kingdom and everyone's smiling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not like that at all. Toshiaki runs up, yelling from the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
